intro: Absinthium campestre, commonly known as field wormwood, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Asteraceae and is characterized by its slender stems and small, yellowish-green flowers. The plant typically grows in meadows and along roadsides, preferring well-drained soils. Its leaves are finely divided and have a strong, bitter aroma due to the presence of sesquiterpene lactones. Absinthium campestre is often used in traditional herbal medicine for its purported digestive and antiseptic properties.

It is commonly found in grasslands, meadows, and disturbed soils across these areas. The plant thrives in temperate climates and is often associated with open, sunny habitats. It is also present in some regions of western Asia. Its distribution spans several countries, including France, Italy, Spain, and Turkey.
